page.title: 12HURLEY VILLAGE,BERKSHIRE
page.content: {HISTORIC HURLEY CONTINUES Monk's Barn circa A.D.1100 next to the carpark(formerly the village pond) is still used for storing potatoes and social occasions. There is an excellently preserved dovecote built by monks in 1306. Alongside this is the tithe barn,now a private house. 'Ye Olde Bell'dating from 1135 was originally the guest house for the monastery of Hurley.It is now an inn. 'The East Arms' is another inn.It was built following the building of the toll road(now a part of the A423) as a coaching inn. Formerly a part of Windsor Forest Hurley gets its name from the HUR meaning "good wood" and LEY meaning meadow.
